name: Seattle Parks and Recreation Before/After School Care
description-card: Recreational child care for children in kindergarten to sixth grade.
description-results: Affordable child care focusing on social, recreational, and physical development. Available to children in kindergarten to sixth grade.
description-jump: Available to children ages 5 - 12 years old, the Seattle Parks and Recreation, in partnership with Associated Recreation Council offers programs that provide kids with activities in areas such as arts and culture, environmental stewardship, health and fitness, academic support, and more.
description: Recreational child care for children 5-12 years old.

text.value: You have a child age 5 (in Kindergarten) to 12 (in grade 6 or below)
Your child can attend a minimum of 60% of days for each program requested
You meet one of the following income requirements
You receive TANF/Welfare benefits
You qualify for the Utility Discount Program
Your family is at or under following income guidelines

stuff_needed: Information about you and each member of your household (Name, Date of birth, Gender, Race/Ethnicity)
Proof of income for all adults. Provide a document that can prove your income. here are some examples:
Preferred: 1040 Income Tax form (most recent)
Gross paycheck stubs (1 month of 32+ hours or 2 months of 31 hours or less for all household before tax income)
Social Security benefits (SSI, Dependent, Disability, Survivor’s, or Retirement) statement or benefit checks
Cash benefits (TANF/Welfare) statement or benefits check
Unemployment Income statement or benefits check
Utility Discount program qualification - provide bill statement (qualifies up to 50% scholarship)
Retirement benefits (Pensions, Annuities, or IRA) statement
Proof of dependents. Documents that can prove your dependent eligibility include:
Preferred: 1040 Income Tax form (most recent)
Birth certificates for dependents
Program selection for each child
how_it_works: School-age care programs are hosted by the Associated Recreation Council (ARC) in partnership with Seattle Parks and Recreation for children and youth ages 5 through 12.
Programs run from September to June.
Vacancies are filled on a rolling basis.
Scholarships are based on household size and parent/guardian income and successful applicants receive a 40% to 90% subsidy as funds are available.
Families apply for scholarships once per year.
Use our website to locate the nearest community center (http://www.seattle.gov/parks/find/centers) or pool facility (http://www.seattle.gov/parks/find/pools).

description-card: Half-day recreational preschool  programs for children 3-5 years.

description-jump: Available to children 3-5 years old not enrolled in school, the Seattle Parks and Recreation, in partnership with Associated Recreation Council operates half-day preschool programs. This program focuses on emotional, social, physical, and cognitive skills to prepare kids for success in school and in life.
description: Half-day recreational preschool  programs for children 3-5 years.

-- Your family is at or under following income guidelines

stuff_needed: Information about you and each member of your household (Name, Date of birth, Gender, Race/Ethnicity)
Proof of income for all adults. Provide a document that can prove your income. here are some examples:

how_it_works: Preschool programs are hosted by the Associated Recreation Council (ARC) in partnership with Seattle Parks and Recreation for children ages 3 - 5.
Classrooms are set up with rich environments, fun-filled learning areas, consistent schedules and routines, and both large and small group times with a low-teacher child ratio of 1:8.
Programs run from September to June.
Vacancies are filled on a rolling basis.
Scholarships are based on household size and parent/guardian income and successful applicants receive a 40% to 90% subsidy as funds are available.
Families apply for scholarships once per year.
Use our website to locate the nearest community center (http://www.seattle.gov/parks/find/centers) or pool facility (http://www.seattle.gov/parks/find/pools).
Fill out scholarship application (https://www.seattle.gov/parks/find/scholarships-and-financial-aid). Application is available in English, Chinese, Somali, Spanish, Vietnamese.

These preschool locations offer scholarships through Seattle Parks and Recreation or free preschool through the Pathway Preschool Program (https://www.seattle.gov/education/early-learning/early-learning-providers/about-our-early-learning-programs/step-ahead-and-spp-pathway):
Alki Community Center
5817 SW Stevens St, Seattle, WA 98116
Ballard Community Center
6020 28th Ave NW, Seattle, WA 98107
Queen Anne Community Center
1901 1st Ave W, Seattle, WA 98119

Bitter Lake Community Center

Meadowbrook Community Center
10517 35th Ave NE, Seattle, WA 98125

name: Seattle Preschool Program
description-card: Get high-quality and affordable preschool for your 3 or 4 year-olds.
description-results: Seattle Preschool Program provides high-quality, and affordable early learning for Seattle's youngest learners.
description-jump: Seattle Preschool Program offers high-quality, affordable preschool to all of Seattle's 3- and 4-year-olds. Students engage in a full time, research-based curriculum taught by certificated staff in a positive school climate and early childhood learning environment.
description: Get high-quality and affordable preschool for your 3 or 4 year-olds.

text.value: *Staff will not ask information about immigration status
You live within Seattle city limits (residents living in unincorporated King County are not eligible)
You have a child age 3 or 4 by August of the participating year
You may be eligible for free or reduced tuition if: You meet the income guidelines based on family size. Calculate your expected tuition here: https://www.seattle.gov/applyspp

stuff_needed: Your preschool selection
Completed application: https://www.seattle.gov/applyspp
how_it_works: Seattle Preschool Programs partners with schools and child care providers to offer preschool for 6 hours per day, 5 days per week.
Flexible schedules, such as part-day or 3 days per week, are not an option. Extended care is available at some sites.
Programs run from September to June.

If you apply by April 1, 2019, you will receive your program assignment, if applicable, no later than April 30. If you apply between April 2 and April 22, 2019, you will receive your program selection no later than May 15. If your child is not selected and placed in Round 1 or 2 -or- your application is received after April 22, you will be placed on a waitlist.
Vacancies are filled on a rolling basis between May 15, 2019 and March 31, 2020.
The application for 2020 – 2021 is expected to open Mid-March 2020.
Tuition is based on household size and parent/guardian income and can be free or on a sliding scale.

text.value: Email: preschool@seattle.gov

person_application: Apply in-person: Seattle Municipal Tower, 17th Floor (Monday to Friday, 8 AM – 4:30 PM, except holidays)
application_info: Application is available in English, Amharic, Chinese, Oromo, Somali, Spanish, and Vietnamese; by email, by fax, or by mail:

address.address_section_addr_line_2: (Monday to Friday, 8 AM – 4:30 PM, except holidays)
address.address_section_phone: (206) 386-1050 (Monday to Friday, 8 AM - 4:30 PM, except holidays)

seo_description: Seattle Preschool Program offers high-quality, affordable preschool to all of Seattle's 3- and 4-year-olds. Students engage in a full time, research-based curriculum taught by certificated staff in a positive school climate and early childhood learning environment.

name: Seattle Promise - College Assistance
description-card: Get financial support and personal guidance needed to succeed in college.
description-results: Get free tuition for the first two years of college and personal guidance needed to succeed.
description-jump: The Seattle Promise program is designed to provide the financial support and personal guidance students need to succeed in college. Students get free tuition and many other supports.
description: Get financial support and personal guidance needed to succeed in college.

text.value: You are a graduating senior from a Seattle Public Schools high school

stuff_needed: Applications for 2019 are closed.
Applications for 2020 will open in fall 2019.
how_it_works: Seattle Promise currently offers up to two years or 90 credits of free tuition to all graduates of six eligible Seattle public high schools regardless of GPA, income, or background. By Fall of 2019, the program will expand to offer this option to all 17 Seattle public high school graduates (graduating class of 2020) who choose to attend either of the three Seattle Colleges. After completing all application requirements, Seattle Promise Scholars will attend workshops designed to prepare them for educational and institutional success.

Seattle Promise Scholars are eligible for the following services: Support applying to Seattle Promise and Seattle Colleges; Support applying for and completing financial aid requirements; Full coverage of any tuition expenses remaining after other scholarships and financial aid; Assistance with choosing and registering for classes; Preparation for the transition to college; Guidance and mentorship through the first two years of college.

text.value: Email: education@seattle.gov

application_info: Applications for 2019 are closed. Applications for 2020 will open in fall 2019, and students can apply online.
seo_description: Get free tuition for the first two years of college and personal guidance needed to succeed.
seo_keywords: free preschool, preschool seattle, seattle preschool program, affordable preschool, low income preschool, free pre k, free school for 3 year olds, free preschool programs

name: Childcare Assistance program
description-card: Get assistance with child care for children up to age 13.
description-results: Get assistance with child care, for children up to age 13, from licensed family child care homes and centers in Seattle.
description-jump: Choose from more than 180 licensed family child care homes and centers in Seattle, which contract with the City to provide high-quality and affordable child care for children up to age 13.
description: Get assistance with child care for children up to age 13.

text.value: You live within Seattle city limits (residents living in unincorporated King County are not eligible)
You are employed and/or enrolled in qualified education or job training program
You have a child under 13 years old
You identify a child care provider contracted with the City of Seattle
You demonstrate ineligibility for any other childcare subsidy program
You meet the income guidelines based on family size:

Families with income that falls below these amounts may be eligible for the State’s Working Connections Child Care (WCCC) program. To apply for WCCC, visit https://www.washingtonconnection.org/eapplication/home.go?action=Introduction&source=

stuff_needed: Your work or school schedule
Proof of your child's age
Proof of your address
Proof of family income
how_it_works: Families can apply at any time during the year. Families are screened for eligibility before submitting unnecessary forms/documentation. Successful applicants receive one voucher per child to cover 25% to 70% of tuition at a qualifying child care provider. Vouchers can be used for full-time, part-time, or before/after school care. Families are responsible for paying the difference between the voucher subsidy amount and the provider's regular monthly rate. Families can choose from over 180 high-quality and affordable child care providers.
You can apply at any time during the year and must recertify eligibility every 12 months

text.value: Email: CCAP@seattle.gov

age_range: Working and student families with 0 - 13 year old children
person_application: Seattle Municipal Tower, 17th Floor (Monday to Friday, 8 AM – 4:30 PM, except holidays)
application_info: Prior to applying, ensure you meet the eligibility criteria by completing the pre-screening. here is the link to the screening form: https://www.seattle.gov/education/for-parents/child-care-and-preschool/child-care-assistance-program. If you cannot fill out the form, provide the following information: Home Address; Email Address; Phone Number; Number of Adults (over 18) in your family; Number of Children in your family (include the age of each child); Are all adults either working or enrolled in school?; What is your family's estimated gross monthly income?; Have you already identified a CCAP provider? If so, who?

address.address_section_addr_line_2: (Monday to Friday, 8 AM – 4:30 PM, except holidays)
address.address_section_phone: Phone: (206) 386-1050 (Monday to Friday, 8 AM - 4:30 PM, except holidays)

seo_title: Child Care Assistance Program (CCAP): Low Income Childcare Help
seo_description: You may be eligible for the Child Care Assistance Program (CCAP). Get 25-70% towards child care for low-income families. Find out if you are eligible in 5 min!

name: Pathway Preschool Program
description-card: Free, flexible schedule, preschool for children ages 3 to 4.
description-results: The Pathway Preschool Program offers families free full and half-day preschool programs for children ages 3 to 4.
description-jump: The Pathway Preschool Program offers families free full and half-day preschool programs for children ages 3 to 4.
description: Free, flexible schedule, preschool for children ages 3 to 4.

text.value: You live within Seattle city limits (residents living in unincorporated King County are not eligible)
You have a child age 3 or 4 by August of the participating year
You meet the income guidelines based on family size

stuff_needed: Proof of your child's age
Proof of your address
Proof of family income
how_it_works: The Pathways Preschool Program provides full- and half-day high-quality preschool programs for 3- and 4-year olds. Preschools are run by community-based organizations and schools, and are located in or near elementary schools. Full-day programs provide 6 or more hours a day for children, 4-5 days a week. Half-day programs provide a 3½ hour instructional day for children, 4 to 5 days a week.
Programs run from September to June. Successful applicants receive free tuition.
These preschool locations offer part-time preschool:
- ARC: Alki Community Center (West Seattle), 206-684-7430
- ARC: Ballard Community Center (Ballard), 206-684-4093
- ARC: Queen Anne Community Center (Queen Anne), 206-386-4240
- Tiny Trees: Beer Sheva Park (Rainier Beach), 206-701-0245
- Tiny Trees: Camp Long (West Seattle), 206-701-0245
- Tiny Trees: Jefferson Bark (Beacon Hill), 206-701-0245
- Tiny Trees: Carkeek Park (Broadview), 206-701-0245
- Voices of Tomorrow: Africa Town (Columbia City), 206-466-1229
- Voices of Tomorrow: East African Development Center (Rainier Beach), 206-466-1229
These preschool locations offer full-time preschool:
- El Centro de la Raza: Jose Martí (Beacon Hill), 206-957-4619
- Hearing, Speech, & Deafness Center (Central District), 206-388-1284
- West African Community Center: One Family Learning Center (Brighton), 206-913-2538
person_application: Apply in-person at the preschool location in which you are interested (see "How it works" for more details).
application_info: Each preschool location manages enrollment directly. We recommend connecting with your preschool of preference to determine if they have vacancies. They will inquire about your family income and size, then will determine if you may be eligible for Pathway. If you are eligible, they will give you an enrollment packet to complete and will need additional documents from you. If you are not eligible for Pathway, they will work with you to determine other preschool options they have for you, including any scholarship opportunities for full-pay preschool seats.

name: Fresh Bucks Match
description-card: A healthy food program that helps Seattle residents afford fresh fruits and vegetables.
description-results: Fresh Bucks is a healthy food program that helps Seattle residents afford fruits and vegetables at participating farmer’s markets and neighborhood grocers.
description-jump: Fresh Bucks is a healthy food program that helps Seattle residents afford fruits and vegetables. If you use SNAP/EBT (food stamps), buy fruits and vegetables using your SNAP benefits and earn matching Fresh Bucks benefits to spend at Fresh Bucks retailers.
description: A healthy food program that helps Seattle residents afford fresh fruits and vegetables.
eligibility:
You may be eligible for Fresh Bucks Match if:
   You use SNAP/EBT (food stamps)

text.value: Must be enrolled in SNAP/EBT and have a valid and active EBT card
If you’re not enrolled in SNAP/EBT, you can check your eligibility at Washington Connection https://www.washingtonconnection.org/home

stuff_needed: A valid and active SNAP/EBT card
how_it_works: Anyone who buys fruits and vegetables with their SNAP/EBT benefits can get $1 worth of Fresh Bucks for every $1 you spend on fruits and vegetables at participating Fresh Bucks retailers.
AT THE FARMERS MARKET:
1. Go to the market’s Information Booth
2. Swipe your EBT card for the amount you want to spend
3. You’ll receive that amount in EBT tokens AND that same amount in Fresh Bucks dollars
4. Shop for fruits and vegetables using your Fresh Bucks dollars
AT NEIGHBORHOOD GROCERS AND FARM STANDS:
1. Purchase qualifying fruits and vegetables
2. Pay with your EBT card
3. Get 50% off your fruit and vegetable purchase

text.value: Email: freshbucks@seattle.org
https://www.freshbuckseattle.org/contact-us/

person_application: Apply in-person at any Community Services Office. Use Washington State's website to locate the nearest Community Services Office (https://www.dshs.wa.gov/office-locations).
application_info: To use Fresh Bucks Match, you must receive SNAP/EBT (food stamps or Basic Food Assistance) through Washington State (https://www.dshs.wa.gov/esa/community-services-offices/basic-food). If you receive SNAP/EBT, you are automatically enrolled in Fresh Bucks Match and do not need to apply to use Fresh Bucks Match. Learn more about Fresh Bucks Match: www.freshbuckseattle.org. If you do not receive SNAP/EBT, here are your options.

address.address_section_addr_line_1: DSHS CSD-Customer Service Center, PO Box 11699

seo_title: Fresh Bucks Program: Farmers Market Food Stamps
seo_description: With the Fresh Bucks Program you can double your food stamp for purchasing fresh, local produce at a Seattle farmers market. Find out if you are eligible in 5 min!
seo_keywords: fresh bucks, farmers market food stamps, double food stamps, snap benefits farmers market, fresh bucks program, farmers market double food stamps

name: ORCA LIFT
description-card: ORCA LIFT offers to 50% discount on transit fares.
description-results: ORCA LIFT offers savings of up to 50% on transit. Available to income-qualified riders.
description-jump: ORCA LIFT makes riding transit more affordable. Income-qualified riders can save up to 50% or more on Metro Transit, Kitsap Transit, Sound Transit Link, Sound Transit Regional Express buses, Sounder Trains, King County Water Taxi, and Seattle Streetcar.
description: ORCA LIFT offers up to 50% discount on transit fares.

text.value: People with household income of less than double the federal poverty level (as established by US Health and Human Services Department) qualify for ORCA LIFT.

To get an ORCA LIFT card, you must be between 19 and 64 years of age. Children six through 18 are eligible for an ORCA youth card, which may be obtained free of charge by LIFT cardholders, and those 65 and older are eligible for a Regional Reduced Fare Permit (RRFP) card. People with disabilities may qualify for the RRFP card.

stuff_needed: Proof of Identity
Proof of income ONLY if you do not currently receive Food Stamps (EBT), Apple Health Care (Medicaid), or TANF
how_it_works: Once you qualify for the ORCA LIFT program, you'll receive an ORCA LIFT card registered to your name, with the same features every ORCA card has. You can load an E-purse value on your card to pay for trips one at a time, or load a discounted monthly pass that lets you take unlimited trips for an entire month. But what makes ORCA LIFT special is you have all the power and convenience of the ORCA card system at a fraction of the cost.

With the ORCA LIFT card, income-qualified riders can save up to 50 percent or more on: Metro Transit buses, Kitsap Transit buses, Sound Transit Link light rail, Sound Transit Regional Express buses, Sounder Trains, King County Water Taxi, Seattle Streetcar
person_application: Call 206-553-3000 or 800-756-5437, or use King County's website to find enrollment locations (https://kingcounty.gov/depts/health/locations/health-insurance/coverage/enrollment-assistance/ORCA-LIFT-card.aspx#enrollment-orca#skc).
application_info: ORCA LIFT is offered through King County Metro. You can apply in-person (use use King County's website to find enrollment locations) or over the phone:
seo_title: ORCA LIFT Program: Reduced Fare Orca Card & Montly Pass
seo_description: Save up to 50% on every single trip when you use ORCA LIFT for low income families. Reduced Fare Orca Card & Montly Pass. Find out if you are eligible in 5 min!
seo_keywords: orca lift, orca lift card, reduced fare orca card, orca reduced fare, low income orca card, orca card reduced fare, reduced fare orca, orca lift monthly pass

name: ORCA Opportunity
description-card: Free ORCA cards for middle and high school students enrolled in Seattle Public Schools.
description-results: Free, unlimited 12-month ORCA card for middle and high school students enrolled in Seattle Public Schools.
description-jump: The ORCA Opportunity program distributes free, unlimited 12-month ORCA cards to high school students at Seattle Public Schools, income-qualified middle school students at Seattle Public Schools, and Seattle Promise Scholars. Cards are valid on King County Metro, King County Water Taxi, Seattle Streetcar, Sound Transit, Community Transit, Pierce Transit, Kitsap Transit, and Everett Transit.
description: Free ORCA cards for Seattle Public School high school and income-qualified middle school students, Seattle Promise scholars, and qualified SHA tenants.

text.value: You are a high school student enrolled in seattle Public Schools
You are an income-qualified middle school student in Seattle Public Schools
You are a Seattle Promise Scholar
You are a Seattle Housing Authority (SHA) tenant aged 19-64 who lives at or below 30% AMI: https://www.seattle.gov/transit/orca-opportunity/orca-opportunity-sha-tenants

stuff_needed: High School Students need their Student ID
Middle School Students need a parent signature
Seattle Promise scholars need to be in a good academic standing with the program
how_it_works: ORCA Opportunity is available to qualifying students.
- If you are a high school student enrolled in Seattle Public Schools, no application is necessary, and you can pick up your ORCA card at the main office of your school.

- If you are a Seattle Promise Scholar, no application is necessary, and you can pick up your ORCA Card at your Bridge Program on September 11.  If you miss those dates, please email ORCAOpportunity@seattle.gov.
- If you are a middle school student enrolled in Seattle Public Schools, you must be income-qualified and ineligible for transportation from Seattle Public Schools.
Students who were in the program last year do not need to complete a new application, unless you have transferred to a new school.
The City will verify that students are not eligible for transportation from Seattle Public Schools and then issue students new ORCA cards.
Students should pick up their cards in their attendance office or main office. If you did not participate last year, please submit the application posted.

text.value: Email: ORCAOpportunity@seattle.gov

age_range: Seattle Public School high school and income-qualified middle school students, Seattle Promise scholars, and qualified SHA tenants

application_info: ORCA Opportunity is available to qualifying students.  Every high school student enrolled at Seattle Public Schools is eligible to receive a card and do not need to apply. Seattle Promise Scholars who remain in good standing with the program will automatically receive a card during your Bridge Program and do not need to apply.  Please email ORCA Opportunity with questions.  For income-qualified middle school students, please use the application below.

stuff_needed: Copy of your ID showing proof of age
$5 for the cost  of the card
how_it_works: An ORCA youth card is available to youth aged 6-18. It allows you to pay only $1.50 for your trip including transferring to other services (within a 2 hour window) like Link light rail, Sound Transit buses, Community Transit and other participating agencies.
Note: If you are a Seattle Public Schools student, please see the ORCA Opportunity Section as you may be eligible for a free ORCA card.

name: Vehicle License Fee Rebate
description-card: Get a $20 license fee rebate for cars registered in Seattle.
description-jump: In 2014, voters in the City of Seattle approved a car tab increase to pay for improved transit service.  With this voter-approved proposition, car tabs, also known as Vehicle License Fees, increased to $80 per vehicle per year. With the Vehicle License Fee Rebate program, income-qualified vehicle owners with a car registered in Seattle are eligible to receive a $20 rebate in the form of a check.
description-result: Income-qualified vehicle owners with a car registered in Seattle are eligible to receive a $20 rebate on their license fee.
description: Get a $20 license fee rebate for cars registered in Seattle.

text.value: You are currently enrolled in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) or Seattle Utility Discount Program (UDP)
Your family is at or under following income guidelines during the monthly period prior to applying:

stuff_needed: Government issued identification for all persons 18 years and older. Please provide a copy of one of the items below for each adult: State driver’s license; State identification card; Passport or Permanent Resident Card

Proof that you are currently enrolled in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) or Seattle Utility Discount Program (UDP) -OR- Proof for total gross household income for all persons 18 years and older living in the house during the monthly period prior to applying.
Proof of payment of the $80 Vehicle License Fee
how_it_works: Car tabs, also known as Vehicle License Fees, increased to $80 per vehicle on June 1, 2015.

If you have a car registered in Seattle and meet income requirements, you are eligible to receive a $20 rebate in the form of a check. This is a one-time, yearly $20 savings, rather than a monthly savings.

text.value: Email: CarTabRebate@seattle.gov

person_application: Apply in person at VLFR Program, 810 3rd Ave, Suite #440, Seattle, WA 98104. If you need staff assistance, walk-in hours are Monday to Friday, 8:30-10:30 am, except holidays. If you don't need staff assistance, completed applications can be dropped off Monday to Friday, 8:00 am-4:00 pm.
application_info: You can apply for a Vehicle License Fee Rebate by email, by mail, by phone, or in-person by filling out the online application form first.
seo_title: Vehicle License Fee Rebate For Income Qualified Vehicle Owners
seo_description: You may be eligible for the Vehicle License Fee Rebate Program. Income qualified vehicle owners get a $20 rebate for their car tab renewal. Find out if you qualify!
seo_keywords: vehicle license fee rebate, car tax rebate

name: Low Income Restricted Parking Zone Permit
description-result: Income-eligible vehicle owners can receive a restricted parking zone permit for $10.
description-jump: The Restricted Parking Zone Program was created to help ease parking congestion in residential neighborhoods. Permits generally cost $65. Income-eligible vehicle owners can receive a restricted parking zone permit for $10, which is generally good for 2 years. This is a one-time savings of $55, rather than a monthly savings.
description: Income-eligible vehicle owners can receive a restricted parking zone (RPZ) permit for $10.

text.value: Use this map for guidance on if your address is eligible for an RPZ permit (http://seattlecitygis.maps.arcgis.com/home/webmap/viewer.html?webmap=4a450bdf1e404f34b384ed22aaaa4182). Or you can use our lookup tool to see if your address is eligible for an RPZ permit (https://cosaccela.seattle.gov/Portal/cap/CapEdit.aspx?Module=AddressInquiry&stepNumber=2&pageNumber=1&isFeeEstimator=&TabName=AddressInquiry&agencyCode=SEATTLE).

You are eligible for the low-income discount if you can prove your enrollment in one of the following programs: Supplemental Nutrition Assistance card (formerly food stamps); Energy assistance from Seattle City Light or Puget Sound Energy; Rental assistance from Seattle Housing Authority (Section 8) or copy of rental agreement in SHA property; Temporary Assistance to Needy Families (TANF) check or stub; Lease/rental agreement from Plymouth Housing, CHHIP, or other low-income housing providers; Proof of Supplemental Security Income (SSI) – NOT regular Social Security income; Issuance of King County Metro Transit Low-Income Fare Card (ORCA LIFT); Provider One or Apple Health card. **Other documentation considered on an individual basis.

stuff_needed: Proof of enrollment in one of the following programs: Supplemental Nutrition Assistance card (formerly food stamps); Energy assistance from Seattle City Light or Puget Sound Energy; Rental assistance from Seattle Housing Authority (Section 8) or copy of rental agreement in SHA property; Temporary Assistance to Needy Families (TANF) check or stub; Lease/rental agreement from Plymouth Housing, CHHIP, or other low-income housing providers; Proof of Supplemental Security Income (SSI) – NOT regular Social Security income; Issuance of King County Metro Transit Low-Income Fare Card (ORCA LIFT); Provider One or Apple Health card.
**Other documentation considered on an individual basis.
how_it_works: Income-eligible vehicle owners can receive a restricted parking zone permit for $10 to park on the street in qualifying neighborhood.

text.value: Email: rpzinfo@seattle.gov

person_application: Apply in person at Seattle Municipal Tower, 700 5th Ave. Ste, 3768, Seattle, WA 98104 (Monday to Friday, 8:30 am - 4:30 pm, except holidays).
application_info: You can apply online, by email, by mail, or in-person for a Low Income Restricted Parking Zone Permit:

address.address_section_addr_line_1: Seattle Department of Transportation, Traffic and Parking Permits, PO Box 34996

seo_title: Low Income Restricted Parking Zone Permit
seo_description: You may be eligible for the Low Income Restricted Parking Zone Permit Program. Income-eligible vehicle owners can receive a RPZ permit for $10. Find out if you qualify!

name: Utility Discount Program
description-card: Get discounted rates on Seattle City Light and Seattle Public Utilities bills.
description-result: The Utility Discount Program offers a 60% discount on Seattle City Light bill and a 50% discount on Seattle Public Utilities bill.
description-jump: The Utility Discount Program (UDP) offers eligible customers a 60% discount on their Seattle City Light bill and a 50% discount on their Seattle Public Utilities bill.
description: Get discounted rates on Seattle City Light and Seattle Public Utilities bills.

text.value: You are the homeowner or renter; if a landlord pays all utilities, qualifying low-income tenants may still be eligible for utility financial help.
You have a Seattle City Light and/or Seattle Public Utilities bill in your name.
Your total household income in the one-month prior to applying matches the table below:

stuff_needed: Income documentation for everyone 18 years and older living in your household
Identification for everyone 18 years and older living in your household
how_it_works: Step 1: Check your eligibility for UDP using the 2018 Eligibility Requirements below.
Step 2: Complete your UDP application (see “How to Apply” for an application form).
Step 3: Mail your application to: Utility Discount Program
Step 4: UDP will contact you to complete the application process.
person_application: Apply in person at Utility Discount Program, 810 3rd Ave, Suite #440, Seattle, WA 98104. If you need staff assistance, walk-in hours are Monday to Friday, 8:00-10:00 am and 1:30-3:30 pm, except holidays. If you don't need staff assistance, completed applications can be dropped off Monday to Friday, 8:00 am-4:00 pm.
application_info: You can apply for the Utility Discount Program in-person or by mail by filling out the online application form first. If you need staff assistance, walk-in hours are Monday to Friday, 8:00-10:00 am and 1:30-3:30 pm, except holidays. If you don't need staff assistance, completed applications can be dropped off Monday to Friday, 8:00 am-4:00 pm.

name: Wave Simply Internet
description-card: Get low-cost, high-speed Internet for around $10 a month.
description-result: Get low-cost, high-speed Internet for around $10 a month and get discounted rates on electronics.
description-jump: Get unlimited high-speed internet for $9.95/month plus tax. Free installation and in-home Wi-Fi. No credit checks, contracts or equipment rental fees required. Refurbished laptops available for purchase.
description: Get low-cost, high-speed Internet for around $10 a month.

text.value: You live in an area that offers Wave internet.
You are the homeowner or renter.
You meet one of the following income requirements:
- You qualify for the Utility Discount Program (https://www.seattle.gov/humanservices/services-and-programs/utility-discount-program)
- You qualify for low-income subsidized housing
- You have a child who qualifies for a free or reduced school lunch program

stuff_needed: Your contact information
Proof of your income
If you are using the Seattle Free or Reduced School Lunch Program or City of Seattle Utility Discount Program as proof of your income, no additional information is needed
If you are using the National School Lunch Program’s Free Lunch Program as proof of your income, provide a referral form from your child's school
Photo Identification (examples: driver’s license or Washington identification card)
how_it_works: Simply Internet provides a high-speed connection (up to 10 Mbps) that enables a qualifying household to get online for a low monthly rate of $9.95.Wave provides all necessary installation services and equipment to provide basic connectivity and wireless internet service at no additional fee.

text.value: Email: brenda.tate@seattle.gov

application_info: You can apply for Simply Internet by Wave in-person, by mail, or by email by filling out the online application form first:

name: Free Toilet Program
description-card: Get a free toilet, installation, and recycling of your old water wasting toilet.
description-result: Get a free toilet, installation, and recycling of your old water wasting toilet.
description-jump:
Seattle Public Utilities offers free water-saving toilets for income-qualified

homeowners. Installation of one new toilet and recycling of your old toilet is

provided free of charge. Replacing your old toilet will save water and can save

you up to $300 per year on utility bills.
description: Get a free toilet, installation, and recycling of your old water wasting toilet.

text.value: Staff will not ask information about immigration status
You receive a Seattle Public Utilities bill
You live in the home that you own
You have a toilet that was installed before 2004
Your total household income in the one-month prior to applying matches the table below:

stuff_needed: Income documentation for everyone 18 years and older living in your household
If you are enrolled in the Utility Discount Program, you do not need an application form or proof of income for this program. Your income already qualifies.
how_it_works:
Seattle Public Utilities partners with Sound Generations to deliver the

program. Call Sound Generations-Minor Home Repair at (206) 448-

5751. They will verify that you qualify, then schedule an appointment

to check your toilets, showerheads, and faucet aerators and install

water-saving replacements as needed.

text.value: Email: MHR@soundgenerations.org

age_range: Homeowners who meet income guidelines, live in the home they pay, pay a Seattle Public Utilities bill, and have a toilet that wa installed before 2004
application_info: Call Sound Generations at (206) 448-5751. Staff can use the Language Line (interpretation service) to talk with you in a language other than English, free of charge.

address.address_section_phone: Phone: (206) 448-5751 (Monday to Thursday) 8:00 AM - 4:00 PM, except holidays)
